page.title: 16LOCAL ROADS
page.content: The B1193 is the new name given to the road between Epping and Harlow. Mail coaches used this route, changing horses in Harlow and baiting (eating and resting) at Hockerill.Royal interest in racing led to its improve ment as a route to Newmarket,but even in the 1950s it was a slow route with bends around every farm boundary.In the 1960s after straightening it took heavy trunk road traffic till the M11 was opened.It is still heavily used. The small roads to Rye Hill and Epping Upland follow old boundaries-the age of the hedges bears this out.The one straight part,over the common,is "used like a race track" despite its narrow blind hill-crests,according to a local policeman. The M11 glances through the area in a cutting,with little traffic noise,and has removed much heavy through traffic
